reasoning: The critique targets the appropriateness of modeling AI R&D with a CES production function and treating negative ρ as implying a hard ceiling on “progress speed.” That issue is discussed in the position, but mainly as part of reconstructing the skeptic’s (Epoch-style) objection; the author’s overall stance is that this CES-based compute-bottleneck argument is not very convincing. So even if the critique succeeded, it would mostly undercut the objection the post is arguing against, rather than undermine the post’s conclusion—hence low centrality to the position and low strength against it. Object-level points (CES is a convenient smooth form; GDP vs R&D output mismatch; discontinuous breakthroughs; nonstationary metrics) are generally plausible and mostly correct, and the critique is clear and focused with little fluff.
title: CES production functions may not validly transfer from GDP to research progress
